bestBHT.bht: Paul fearlessly preached and taught, unhindered even in his imprisonment. He continued to be under the watch of a soldier, and the Jews engaged in heated debates and discussions about his teachings. While some manuscripts omit this section without reason, it was likely added to soften the abrupt conclusion of the story. These vigorous disputes showcase the importance of contending against those who reject God, in order to find peace with Him. Striving against opposition is necessary for embracing the truth.

Henry Alford: He preached and taught with all boldness, and unhindered, both being mentioned as remarkable circumstances, and implying that there were reasons why this could hardly have been expected.
It is evident that Paul was not released from custody, but continued with the soldier who kept him.
On the whole question regarding the chronology of his imprisonment, and the reason of this abrupt ending of the history…
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The Jews departed, and had great reasoning among themselves.
This verse is wanting in many manuscripts [and omitted by several recent editors], but certainly without reason.
Probably the words were regarded as superfluous, as they seem to tell us what we were told before, that Paul 'departed' (see :-).
Albert Barnes: The part which believed that Jesus was the Messiah discussed the subject warmly with those who did not believe.
This whole verse is missing in the Syriac version, and in some Greek mss., and is supposed by Mill and Griesbach to be spurious.
John Calvin: They are so far from waxing meek when they are reproved, that they are more inflamed with fury."
But seeing there was such disputing, it appeareth that some did so embrace those things which Paul had spoken, that they doubted not to defend and stoutly to avouch that which they believed.
Assuredly, if we will have peace with God, we must strive against those which contemn him.
Philip Schaff: The whole of this verse is wanting in the more ancient MSS. and versions, and must be considered spurious.
It was, however, probably added in early times by some scribe, to soften down the apparent abruptness of the close of the account of the interview between Paul and the leading Jews of Rome.
...to soften down the apparent abruptness of the close of the account...
John Gill: and had great reasoning among themselves; not only with them that believed, but with others
that seemed to incline towards the apostle, and who espoused and undertook to defend some principles of his
things which must be very grating to them

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul preached and taught boldly and without hindrance, despite the remarkable circumstances surrounding his imprisonment. It is evident that he remained in custody, continuing to be under the watchful eye of a soldier. There were debates and discussions among the Jews, some staunchly defending their beliefs and others embracing the teachings of Jesus passionately. While some manuscripts omit this verse without reason, it is likely that it was added by a scribe to soften the abruptness of the account's conclusion. These vigorous disputes reveal the intense fervor with which the Jews either rejected or defended Paul's words, making it clear that striving against those who reject God is necessary for peace with Him.

Paul fearlessly preached and taught, unhindered even in the face of challenging circumstances during his captivity. He remained in custody with a soldier guarding him, and passionate debates and discussions arose among the Jews, some defending Paul's teachings. While some manuscripts omit this verse without reason, it seems likely that a scribe added it to soften the abrupt ending of the account. These fervent disputes illustrate the need to strive against those who reject God, in order to find peace with Him.
